title: Biden adviser calls on Australia to 'blunt' China
text:
China 'challenge'

He said the "China challenge" over the next 30 to 40 years would be more difficult for the US and its allies than the four-decade Cold War against Soviet expansionism which ended with the collapse of the USSR in 1991.

"We must deepen our alliance and ask more of each other," Mr Burns said at the Lowy Institute event at the National Press Club on Wednesday night.

"We would like to see Australia play a bigger role."

Defence Minister Linda Reynolds on Thursday said the defence budget was on track to increase to 2 per cent of GDP in 2020-21. Defence spending fell to 1.56 per cent under the Rudd-Gillard Labor government, the lowest share since the 1930s.

"Defence is currently undertaking a review of our planning against changes in the strategic environment, technology and threats over the 2020 to 2040 time frame," Ms Reynolds said.

M &A deals blocked

Mr Burns endorsed the government blocking Chinese acquisitions of strategic assets and technology, an ostensible reference to the government rejecting China-linked bids for electricity networks and gas pipelines, as well as banning telco Huawei from supplying the 5G wireless network.

"Australia has been clamping down on Chinese efforts to acquire significant assets here. We've been doing the same," Mr Burns said.

Xi Jinping is waging an ideological war. — Nicholas Burns, adviser to Joe Biden

He praised Prime Minister Scott Morrison's Pacific "step up", including his third recent trip to Fiji to build relations with small neighbouring countries that China is trying to influence.

The Harvard Kennedy School professor of international relations accused China's President Xi Jinping of "waging an ideological war".

"He is asserting the primacy of the Chinese Communist Party authoritarian system as a model for the rest of the world."

Mr Burns is currently an adviser to Mr Biden, a former US vice-president under Barack Obama and one of the Democratic frontrunners for the 2020 presidential nomination.

During his visit to Canberra Mr Burns met the Prime Minister's office, Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese, and officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs and intelligence agencies.

Lowy Institute senior fellow Richard McGregor said regardless of who was leading the US, Australians should expect "full-spectrum competition between the US and China for many years to come".

Mr Burns said Republicans and Democrats were broadly united in treating China as a strategic competitor because it had not played by the international trade rules and had "ripped off" US intellectual property, costing Americans jobs.

Mr Morrison recently sided with President Trump by calling on China to be recognised as a newly developed economy in the global trading system.

Mr Burns said more work needed to be done on the fledgling quadrilateral partnership between Australia, the US, Japan and India to offset China's growing assertiveness in the Indo-Pacific, including its island building in the South China Sea.

"This is not a quad to contain China, it's a quad to limit China," Mr Burns said.

He expressed hope that if Mr Trump, who he described as an American "outlier", was defeated at the November 2020 election, US global leadership could be restored under a Democratic president.
description: US presidential candidate Joe Biden's foreign policy adviser has called on the Morrison government to increase defence spending to help limit China's rise.
